item.text: Tektology is proto system sciene.

Tektology is regarded a precursor of system science.  Term is coined by Russian writer Alexander Bogdanov to describe a discipline that consisted of unifying all social, biological and physical sciences by considering them as systems of relationships and by seeking the organizational principles that underlie all systems

Tektology is regarded a precursor of system science.  Term is used by Russian writer Alexander Bogdanov to describe a discipline that consisted of unifying all social, biological and physical sciences by considering them as systems of relationships and by seeking the organizational principles that underlie all systems

Tektology is regarded a precursor of system science.  Term is used by Russian writer Alexander Bogdanov to describe a discipline that consisted of unifying all social, biological and physical sciences by considering them as systems of relationships and by seeking the organizational principles that underlie all systems.

Tektology: Universal Organization Science, published in Russia between 1912 and 1917, anticipated many of the ideas that were popularized later by Norbert Wiener in Cybernetics and Ludwig von Bertalanffy in the General Systems Theory.

Tektology is regarded a precursor of system science.  Term is used by Russian writer Alexander Bogdanov to describe a discipline that consisted of unifying all social, biological and physical sciences by considering them as systems of relationships and by seeking the organizational principles that underlie all systems - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tektology wikipedia]

Tektology: Universal Organization Science, published in Russia between 1912 and 1917, anticipated many of the ideas that were popularized later by [[Norbert Wiener]] in [[Cybernetics]] and [[Ludwig von Bertalanffy]] in the General [[Systems Theory]].

The aim of Tectology is the systematization of organized experience", through the identification of universal organizational principles: "all things are organizational, all complexes could only be understood through their organizational character. This is (historically) the first identification of philosophical "complexes" in the natural sciences to denote a combination of elements of `activity - resistance'.
Bogdanov considered that any complex should correspond to its environment and adapt to it. A stable and organized complex is greater than the sum of its parts.

In Tectology, the term 'stability' refers not to a dynamic stability, but to the possibility of preserving the complex in the given environment. A 'complex' is not identical to a 'complicated, a hard-to-comprehend, large unit
<H3>History
<H3>History

Tektology: Universal Organization Science, published in Russia between 1912 and 1917, anticipated many of the ideas that were popularized later by [[Norbert Wiener]] in [[Cybernetics]] and [[Ludwig von Bertalanffy]] in the General [[Systems Theory]].
Originally the term "tektology" denoted "a branch of morphology that regards an organism as made up of other organisms" (from Greek œÑŒ≠Œ∫œÑœâŒΩ, tekt≈çn "builder").

The term "tektology" was first used by Ernst Haeckel to describe "a branch of morphology that regards an organism as made up of other organisms" (from Greek œÑŒ≠Œ∫œÑœâŒΩ, tekt≈çn "builder") - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Haeckel wikipedia]

Bogdanov applied the term Tektology: Universal Organization Science, published in Russia between 1912 and 1917, anticipated many of the ideas that were popularized later by [[Norbert Wiener]] in [[Cybernetics]] and [[Ludwig von Bertalanffy]] in the General [[Systems Theory]].

Tektology is regarded a precursor of system science.  The Russian writer Alexander Bogdanov appropriated the term to describe a discipline that consisted of unifying all social, biological and physical sciences by considering them as systems of relationships and by seeking the organizational principles that underlie all systems - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tektology wikipedia]

Tektology is regarded a precursor of system science.  The Russian writer [[Alexander Bogdanov]] appropriated the term to describe a discipline that consisted of unifying all social, biological and physical sciences by considering them as systems of relationships and by seeking the organizational principles that underlie all systems - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tektology wikipedia]

My interest in this term is partly it's beauty, partly it's historical pedigree, but mostly because it captures and helps picture many ideas related to society, hypertext and learning that I've been working with since the 1990's.
<H3>Co-opting the Term

My interest in this term is partly it's beauty, partly it's historical pedigree, but mostly because it captures and helps picture many ideas related to society, hypertext and learning that I've been working with since the 1990's.
<H3>Co-opting the Term
<H3>Let's Repurpose Tektology!
<H3>Remixing Tektology!
Bogdanov himself remixed the term from the original use by Ernst Haeckel. I propose that we do the same - and admix the ideas of maps, mapping and tecktonic plates.
Bogdanov himself remixed the term from the original use by Ernst Haeckel. I propose that we do the same - and admix the ideas of [[Maps and Mapping]] and [[Tectonic Plates]].
<H3>Remixing Tektology
Tektology is regarded a precursor of system science.

The Russian writer [[Alexander Bogdanov]] appropriated the term to describe a discipline that consisted of unifying all social, biological and physical sciences by considering them as systems of relationships and by seeking the organizational principles that underlie all systems - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tektology wikipedia]
Tektology is regarded a precursor of system science. I'm proposing reusing this term for a new science of topographical representation of fluid, but stable complexes of thought.

My interest in this term is partly it's beauty, partly it's historical pedigree, but mostly because it helps picture many ideas related to society, hypertext and learning that I've been working with since the 1990's.
In particular I am interested in the mapping of related concepts using geographical metaphors - for instance using the [[GMap Algorithm]].

In particular I am interested in the mapping of related concepts using geographical metaphors - for instance using the [[GMap Algorithm]]. Other related elements of this [[Meme]] are [[Liquid Graph Theory]], and [[Ideas with Voices]], and the [[Legal Constitution of Fluid Groups]].

In particular I am interested in the mapping of related concepts using geographical metaphors - for instance using the [[Drawing Graphs as Maps]]. Other related elements of this [[Meme]] are [[Liquid Graph Theory]], and [[Ideas with Voices]], and the [[Legal Constitution of Fluid Groups]].

story.text: [[Alexander Bogdanov]], founder of [[Tektology]], who vied with Lenin for the leadership of the Bolshevik faction - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Bogdanov wikipedia]

In particular I am interested in the mapping of related concepts using geographical metaphors - for instance using the [[Drawing Graphs as Maps]]. Other related elements of this [[Meme]] are [[Liquid Graph Theory]], and [[Ideas with Voices]], and the [[Legal Constitution of Fluid Groups]].

My interest in this term is partly it's beauty, partly it's historical pedigree, but mostly because it helps picture many ideas related to society, hypertext and learning that I've been working with since the 1990's.
Bogdanov himself remixed the term from the original use by Ernst Haeckel. I propose that we do the same - and admix the ideas of [[Maps and Mapping]] and [[Tectonic Plates]].

The aim of Tectology is the systematization of organized experience", through the identification of universal organizational principles: "all things are organizational, all complexes could only be understood through their organizational character. This is (historically) the first identification of philosophical "complexes" in the natural sciences to denote a combination of elements of `activity - resistance'.
Bogdanov considered that any complex should correspond to its environment and adapt to it. A stable and organized complex is greater than the sum of its parts.
In Tectology, the term 'stability' refers not to a dynamic stability, but to the possibility of preserving the complex in the given environment.

The term "tektology" was first used by Ernst Haeckel to describe "a branch of morphology that regards an organism as made up of other organisms" (from Greek œÑŒ≠Œ∫œÑœâŒΩ, tekt≈çn "builder") - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Haeckel wikipedia]

The Russian writer [[Alexander Bogdanov]] appropriated the term to describe a discipline that consisted of unifying all social, biological and physical sciences by considering them as systems of relationships and by seeking the organizational principles that underlie all systems - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tektology wikipedia]
This anticipated many of the ideas that were popularized later by [[Norbert Wiener]] in [[Cybernetics]] and [[Ludwig von Bertalanffy]] in the General [[Systems Theory]].
